article.paragraph:
Aeacus was the son ofZeusandAegina (mythology)Aegina, a daughter of the river-godAsopus.CitationSchmitz Leonhard

Nonn. Dionys. vi. 212Ovid,Metamorphosesvi. 113, vii. 472, &c.According to some accounts Aeacus was a son of Zeus andEuropa (mythology)Europa. Some traditions related that at the time when Aeacus was born,Aeginawas not yet inhabited, and that Zeus changed the ants (langgrcμύρμηκες) of the island into men (Myrmidons) over whom Aeacus ruled, or that he made men grow up out of the earth.Hesiod,Fragm.67, ed. GottlingPausanias (geographer)Pausanias,l.c.Ovid, on the other hand, supposes that the island was not uninhabited at the time of the birth of Aeacus, and states that, in the reign of Aeacus,Hera, jealous of Aegina, ravaged the island bearing the name of the latter by sending a plague or a fearfuldragoninto it, by which nearly all its inhabitants were carried off, and that Zeus restored the population by changing the ants into men.Ovid,Metamorphosesvii. 520comp. Hygin.Fab.52Strabo, viii. p. 375

These legends seem to be a mythical account of the colonization of Aegina, which seems to have been originally inhabited byPelasgians, and afterwards received colonists fromPhthiotis, the seat of the Myrmidons, and fromPhliuson theAsopus. Aeacus while he reigned in Aegina was renowned in all Greece for his justice and piety, and was frequently called upon to settle disputes not only among men, but even among the gods themselves.Pindar,Isthmian Odesviii. 48, &c.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias, i. 39. 5He was such a favourite with the latter, that, when Greece was visited by adroughtin consequence of a murder which had been committed, the oracle of Delphi declared that the calamity would not cease unless Aeacus prayed to the gods that it might.Diodorus Siculus, iv. 60, 61Aeacus prayed, and it ceased in consequence. Aeacus himself showed his gratitude by erecting a temple to Zeus Panhellenius on mount Panhellenion,Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias, ii. 30. 4and the Aeginetans afterwards built a sanctuary in their island called Aeaceum, which was a square place enclosed by walls of white marble. Aeacus was believed in later times to be buried under the altar in this sacred enclosure.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias, ii. 29. 6

A legend preserved inPindarrelates thatApolloandPoseidontook Aeacus as their assistant in building the walls of Troy.Pindar,Olympian Odesviii. 39, &c.When the work was completed, threedragonsrushed against the wall, and while the two of them which attacked those parts of the wall built by the gods fell down dead, the third forced its way into the city through the part built by Aeacus. Hereupon Apollo prophesied thatTroywould fall through the hands of Aeacus's descendants, theAeacidae.

Aeacus was also believed by the Aeginetans to have surrounded their island with high cliffs to protect it againstpiracypirates.Pausanias (geographer)Pausanias, ii. 29. 5Several other incidents connected with the story of Aeacus are mentioned byOvid.Ovid,Metamorphosesvii. 506, &c., ix. 435, &cByEndesAeacus had two sons,Telamon(father ofAjax (mythology)AjaxandTeucer) andPeleus(father ofAchilles), and byPsamathe (Nereid)Psamathea son,Phocus, whom he preferred to the two others, both of whom contrived to kill Phocus during a contest, and then fled from their native island.

After his death, Aeacus became (along with theMinoan CreteCretanbrothersRhadamanthusandMinos) one of the three judges inHades,Ovid,Metamorphosesxiii. 25Horace,Carmenii. 13. 22and according toPlatoespecially for the shades of Europeans.Plato,Gorgias (dialogue)Gorgiasp. 523Isocrates,Evag.5In works of art he was represented bearing a sceptre and the keys of Hades.Pindar,Isthmian Odesviii. 47, &c.Aeacus had sanctuaries both atAthensand inAegina,HesychiusDisambiguation neededFebruary 2012s.v.Schol.ad Pind. Nem.xiii. 155and the Aeginetans regarded him as the tutelary deity of their island and celebrated theAeaceain his honor.Pindar,Nemean Odesviii. 22

InThe Frogs(405 BC) byAristophanes,Dionysusdescends toHadesand announces himself asHeracles. Aeacus lamentsHeracles's theft ofCerberusand sentencesDionysustoAcheronand torment by hounds ofCocytus,Echidna (mythology)Echidna, the Tartesian eel, and Tithrasian Gorgons.
Alexander the Greattraced his ancestry (through his mother) to Aeacus.
